shortcv.p: Dimitris Mitropoulos holds a BSc in Informatics and Telecommunications from the National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, an MSc in Information Systems from the Athens University of Economics and Business and a PhD in Cyber Security from the Athens University of Economics and Business. He has worked in the industry as a software engineer and has been involved in several EU funded R&D projects. Currently, he is the project manager of the TRACER project. His research interests include computer security, intrusion detection systems, static code analysis, software evolution and software engineering. He is an IEEE member, an OWASP member, a member of SysSec, and an official writer for the XRDS:Crossroads blog of ACM.

phd-info.phd-summary: Code injection attacks are one of the most damaging class of attacks because: they can occur in different layers, like databases, native code, applications, libraries and others; and they span a wide range of security and privacy issues, like viewing sensitive information, destruction or modification of sensitive data, or even stopping the execution of the entire application. Our research attempts to prevent a wide class of such attacks in a novel way.
